title.rendered: Is Too Much Minecraft Harmful for Kids With ADHD?

content.rendered:
Key Points: Minecraft can be used as a learning tool for children with ADHD, but playing too much can prevent children from developing other interests. There are strategies parents can use to get the most out of Minecraft, limit playtime, and encourage more diverse activities.

COVID-19 has ruled our lives for almost a year. Over the course of this year, screen time has suddenly become acceptable and safer than the alternatives. But for millions of kids, the extra screen time at the start of the school year hasn’t returned to normal. Children whose schools remain closed, who are in hybrid models, or whose parents want them at home still spend a lot of time in front of their screens doing homework and games. And if you have a child between the ages of 6 and 12, chances are they’re an expert at Minecraft.

This experience is usually more pronounced in children with learning disabilities or ADHD, because Minecraft is a game that offers what they rarely experience in science: errors are easily corrected, the pace of play is usually not an issue, and it generates attention and sustained Persistence. .

Instead of fighting your child’s Minecraft game, see it as an opportunity to develop cognitive, executive, and social-emotional skills. If during the summer you’ve insisted that your son get outside, exercise, jump in the water every now and then and have a good time with his family, you probably did your best, considering the circumstances. If you want to know if you really have been playing too much Minecraft and if it has harmed you, read on.

Minecraft can teach children a variety of skills

What about Minecraft? If your child with ADHD or learning disabilities enjoys playing Minecraft, then like many other children, they do. But sometimes kids with ADHD get too focused on their favorite activities, and Minecraft (as well as other video games) can be one of those interests. Games like Minecraft, which have no beginning or end, are not easy to put down, and as a result, some children with ADHD may show an obsessive interest in spending too much time playing or thinking about the game.

Parents may wonder if so much Minecraft is good for kids with ADHD. Probably not, but it’s not that bad either. Minecraft allows children to practice a variety of executive skills, such as B. planning, flexibility and organization, and promotes creativity, collaboration, digital literacy and other skills of the XNUMX. century. Kids learn history, math, physics, and geology while playing Minecraft, and it can spark an interest in architecture, art, electronics, and construction.

Too much Minecraft limits interest in other activities

However, Minecraft can be harmful to children with ADHD if that’s all they do. If your child insists on spending all their free time playing Minecraft, you need to find an effective way to set boundaries and encourage other interests. Perhaps most importantly, you also encourage your child to participate in activities such as outdoor play, sports, and going out with friends. If you want them to play with technology, try to put their love of Minecraft into practice by learning coding skills, making Minecraft videos, trying new games or playing Lego. Expanding the interests of children with ADHD helps them stay focused in all situations.

If your child only seems to be thinking about Minecraft (or another favorite video game), you may need to take more specific action by setting boundaries. These simple strategies can help:

Minecraft can serve as a source for learning new information on various subjects if used in moderation.

Source: from Mint_Images / Shutterstock

1. Give school priority. Only allow Minecraft to play after all schoolwork has been successfully completed. If your child is in distance learning, look for tools to turn off Minecraft during school.

2. Make Minecraft a social moment. Insist that time in Minecraft takes place in collaboration with friends from school or from the neighborhood. Many of your friends are likely Minecraft players too, and given the challenges of organizing regular playdates during COVID-19, Minecraft is a safe and potentially educational activity.

3. Talk about his Minecraft goals before playing. Join a discussion that challenges your child to use skills like planning, metacognition, and sustained attention in Minecraft play. One of the reasons many educators use Minecraft as a learning tool is that it requires executive functions and academic skills.

4. Develop your interests beyond Minecraft. Insist that they try other sandbox games, consider making Let’s Play videos, or ask them to teach you or your younger siblings how to play Minecraft. Better yet, use Minecraft as a tool to learn about architecture, history, or science.

Too much technology or interest can be overwhelming because it prevents children from learning more about the rest of the world. It can be difficult to set boundaries when a child with ADHD or learning disabilities is the happiest, most focused, and least recalcitrant child when it comes to electronics. This task is even more difficult when playing Minecraft is safer than other activities. Still, it’s a good long-term strategy for avoiding too much Minecraft.
